newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: Spain's debt market closed lower on Friday, but off lows, outperforming Italian bonds in London.
Dealers remained wary, and see the trend as highly volatile short run ahead of this weekend's G7 meeting and after the latest Japanese market rate overnight.
Domestic buying interest was emerging at around a seven percent yield, or at 112.30/40 for futures.
"Foreign investors bought something this morning, but very little," a dealer at Credit Lyonnais in Madrid said. "The main business here is still trading, with no final demand".
Trading volume was low, partly because of a holiday in Italy.
Yields on Spanish 18-month bills are seen debuting on Monday at around 5.31/32 percent with firm demand.
Yields of one-year bills are expected either to remain steady or fall a bit from 5.363 percent set on April 16.
The Spanish yield curve steepened a bit.
"To invest short end is our safe choice when the market's direction is not clear enough," another dealer in Madrid said.
Others stressed that there are growing expectations of possible further monetary easing for mid-May, after the May 14 release of April's consumer price index.
